dialogues.speaker: CHET, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Countless millions of Americans, for years upon years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deer drinks.

dialogues.speaker: CHET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +.» have sought refuge from the harsh detachment and sterile serenity of modern life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squirrel is sitting on a branch.

dialogues.speaker: CHET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -... in the honest embrace of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A goose and her goslings paddle through the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: CHET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They return again and again to refresh their weary souls, restore their battered faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stand of virgin pine.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Renew... the ties that bind. To marvel at the wonders of nature...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woodpecker beats against a pine.

dialogues.speaker: CHET, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: -.. and enjoy the boundless rewards...

dialogues.speaker: ESTABLISH
dialogues.text: A quiet, little resort made up of a dozen quaint log lodges, a modest beach and boat dock, a raft, some fishing beats, an office, bar and game room and lots of stately pines between two of which is the Ripley family's station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We meet the Ripley's. Behind the wheel is the father, CHET. He's in his late-thirties. He wears his hair in a straight business cut. Beside him is his wife, CONNIE. She's in her late~thirties. Attractive, strong and independent. In the back seat are their children. BEN, 8, and BUCK, 13. Ben is precocious, impish and somewhat detached from the normal interest of a boy his age. Suck is handsome, quiet and controlled. Chet is finishing his grand speech.

dialogues.speaker: CHE
dialogues.text: ... of the pure and simple style of life that prevails in the Big Country. Chet takes a moment to enjoy his speech. The rest of the family sits unimpressed and unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Chet's speech rings a bell. He thinks for a moment, then looks at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN AND BUCK
dialogues.text: They exchange looks. The speech is familiar to Ben as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck leans forward in the seat, between Connie and Chet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7  8 io

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Dad? You read that off the brochure that came with the fishing poles. Chet clears his throat to cover his embarrassment at getting caught quoting a brochure.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: So what if I did? It doesn't matter where it came from, it's true and we're going to experience every bit of it.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: If we're going to experience every bit of it, shouldn't we get out of the car?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Let's go! All four family members swing their doors open.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STATION WAGON
dialogues.text: All four station wagon deers open simultaneously —— WEAM! ~~ into pine trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Connie with a big grin.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Whoa! Trees in the parking lot! What a place! Nature everywhere you park!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small, knotty pine room with a desk, stuffed chairs, rag rugs and a fireplace over which hangs a moosenead. The fur on.the moose's nose is long gone from thirty years of petting by guests and their chil- dren. A small restaurant if off to one side, a bar with a couple of old lushes nailed to the bar. Chet opens the door and peeks in. He walks in. He's over- come by a wave of nostalgia. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 il

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Oh, for God’s sake. Just like IT remember it. Oooh. The moose. He looks at the moosehead.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: The nose is badly worn from pecple rubbing it and the eyes are crossed. EXT. OFFICE - DAY lL Connie and the boys are outside the office, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This is going to be a living hell.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What happened to us going to California?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Dad decided on Lake Potowota...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: ».. minimac.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: I know, but why?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He has his reasons and I don't think it's your place to question his decisions.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This is an extension of the working father guilt syndrome thing. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't think there's anything wrong with us spending a week together at a nice lake tesort.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Did you want to come here? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: iL 12 CONTINUED: il

dialogues.speaker: . CONNIE
dialogues.text: O£ course not. I wanted to go to California like any other normal person would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet is standing before the mounted moosehead. He raises his right hand and lifts his little finger, closes his eyes and with the other hand rubs the moose's nose. He recites a brief North Woods incanta- tion.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Ahnaweeo, anasaugatuck, Bring this little boy a bundle of luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adjacent to the office. A couple of REGULARS look over their shoulders as they hear Chet CHANTING. THEIR P.O.V. Chet's in the Lobby with his raised hand, chanting Indian jibberish, rubbing the moose's nose.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: They trade curious looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet fishes into his pocket for a penny. He holds the penny in one hand, his hand is on the moose's nose.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Winna-laka-missee, bunkachu-go, To praise the great Indian Chief a new penny I throw. He tosses the penny over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: INT, BAR
dialogues.text: The penny lands in the bowl of complimentary cheddar cheese fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet turns to see where the penny landed. He sees the regulars looking at him. He feels slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I used to do this with my dad when I was a kid. Didn't you used to do this... with... your dad? No? I£ you'll excuse me, I have to check in. Thanks. And sorry. Keep the change. He offers a limp smile and strolls to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hello? There's no response. Chet peeks back into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (continuing) I love the woods. He smiles again. Connie and the boys enter the office.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well? Is this a real North Woods lodge? Suh? Boys? Isn't this rugged? Check out the shotgun lamp over there. Chet points out, Buck and Ben look. THEIR P.O.V. A shotgun that's been made into a lamp. [t's standing on end with a light bulb screwed into the barrel and a small shade on the bulb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet's very proud. Buck and Ben are not terribly im- pressed. Chet leans over the lobby counter.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Hello?  13 14 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged man and a middle-aged woman are asleep in the stuffed chairs in a small office behind the front desk. WALLY and JUANITA MOBERT. They're snoring gencly. He's in bermuda shorts, an “I'VE BEEN TO DULUTH" t-shirt, black knee socks, leather sandals and a Milwaukee Brewer's cap, Juanita is wearing a sun- dress, peds, cheap jogging shoes and a Budweiser visor. Hello? CHET (0.S.) ello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet leans over the desk peeking into the backroom. He can't see Wally and Juanita.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Anybody home? He turns back to Connie.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (continuing) Can you imagine an unattended motel office in Chicago? No way. This is good, old-fashioned North Woods trust. Be looks down on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little plastic pawderhorn lays on a nand-printed sign that reads: "FOR PROMPT SERVICE, BLOW ME." The first three words are on one line. "BLOW ME" is below and in italics.

dialogues.speaker: CEET
dialogues.text: He picks up the horn and looks at it distastefully. He wipes it on his sleeve and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Neat little touch, hun?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) Charming. Chet puts the horn to his lips and blows it softly. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: No sound. He looks at the end of the little horn to see if it's clogged. He fills his lungs and blows with all his might. Still no sound. He puts it to his lips again and blows a third time. Suddenly, a huge, © Ye mixed-breed German Shepherd with a snout covered with porcupine quills and burrs leaps up from behind the desk and barks an inch from Chet'’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BACKROOM - WALLY AND JUANITA - DAY 1s They're blasted from their slumber.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Ho!

dialogues.speaker: SUANITA
dialogues.text: Hup! They look around. Get their bearings, realize someone's at the desk. In unison, they rock back and forward, back and forward and up and out of the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They waddle out of the backroom.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Howdy, folks. Don't mind Wormer. She don't care for people. (yells to the dog) Shut the frig up! Wormer stops in mid-bark. Wally pulls the dog down and it retreats back to its position under the counter.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now, what can I do you folks for? HIS P.O.¥. The Ripley's are paralyzed with fear. Frozen expres ~ sions of horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mercedes station wagon speeds along the highway.  18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family admires a beautiful log cabin. Chet pulls up behind them and gets out of the wagon. Connie's impressed. Even Buck and Ben are pleased. Wally and Juanita flank the family. They love the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: You city dwelling fools are damn lucky to have this place. It just come available this morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (proud) This is a dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Yep. We call it the Loon's Nest.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: {to Ben) You ever seen a loon, noodlehead?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We have one in our family.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie steps in front of Ben to quiet him.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: We had a fishing party in there up till yesterday. They caught their limit and blew. It's all redecorated inside. Wally and me sunk over 300 bucks into it, not counting what we spent in lysol. Beautiful. Nothing within a hundred miles compares. Not even the Holiday inn. Chet puts his arm around Connie and gives her a little hug.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: I think Juanita here owes me a liverwurst sandwich and a glass of buttermilk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: You folks enjoy your stay.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: In a place like this, how could we not?

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: You could get the shits from the well water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes we saw earlier flies down the two-lane, blows its horn and whips around a slow-moving car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and Chet sweeps his arm. A grand introduction to the interior. Connie and the boys stare. Chet looks. His big smile fades. CHET'S P.O.V. The cabin is dirty and cluttered. The remains of a pizza and beer blast from the previous party is quietly molding on the tables. Newspapers, magazines, fishing gear, buckets, cans, trash bags, dust, cobwebs and rubbish. The building itself is beautiful in its own right but is ebviously uncared for. [It needs a good cleaning. The furnishings are straight, standard cot~ tage sofas and chairs. Except for a large oil portrait of JFK, Elvis Presley and Vince Lombardi wearing halos.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Looks for the bright side.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Just think how much we're going to have to appreciate when we get back home! A lame laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes station wagon flies through the trees and grinds to a stop outside the lodge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 ll. CONTINUED: aL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tt opens and we RISE to reveal pastel slacks, polo shirt with a man's hand sporting a diamond pinky ring, a gold Rolex planted on his lower belly and sleek sunglasses. The dark glasses are slowly and dramati- cally removed and we meet ROMAN CRAIG.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: What a gas! Chet's gonna shit plutonium pellets! What a solid surprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We meet his family. His attractive and chic wife, KATE, his twin nine-year-old daughters, CARA and MARA. Kate's in an expensive blouse and skirt. Cara and Mara are in sundresses embroidered with their names. Strange, withdrawn children.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: I'll go £ind out where Chet's bivouacked the family.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: This is very unfair, Roman.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? We're family for crying out loud. Listen, how many times have we invited Chet and Connie to the Islands with us? A billion?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: This is a little different. We weren't invited.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: They'll be tickled to death to see us. What the hell is there to do up here? Fish?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I just hate to impose.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Impose? Don't you want to be with your sister? When was the last time you saw her? (CONTINUED)
22 We talked last week. And she said she was looking forward to gett:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ag away from everything and everyone. I want to see her. I don't wane to impose on her.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, if you can't impose on your family, who the hell can you impose on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 Connie's cleaning the stovetop. The kitchen has been cleaned. Chet walks in, freshly showered. behind Connie and kisses her neck.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: What're you doing? Get your bathing suit on and let's go to the lake.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You go ahead. I can't relax in filth. Chet turns her around ané wraps her in his

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: We'll all pitch in and clean the place tonight. Be gives her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CHET'S HANDS
dialogues.text: He's unzipping Connie's skirt.

dialogues.speaker: CHET AND CONNIE
dialogues.text: He walks up His persuasion isn't working. Chet is undaunted.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We can't even use the bathroom until someone finds the toilet seat.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Buck found it on the sunporch. You have no further excuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her skirt drops to her ankles.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE AND CHET
dialogues.text: Connie struggles against his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Chet!

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: The kids are outside.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't care. Chet drops the shoulder straps on her top.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Ooops! Connie's top slips down to her waist. Chet goes for her bra.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Stop iti

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: What? I'm helping you get into your bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I'Ll go to the bedroom, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: There's no need for that. This is the North Woods. You can walk around naked as a bear and nct worry about running into anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and we see Roman and Kate. Kate's jaw drops in embarrassment. Roman smiles. THEIR P.O.V. Connie and Chet embracing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her skirt's at her ankles, her blouse is at her waist and her bra's hanging on Chet’s finger.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: One of the great moments in his life.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE AND CHET
dialogues.text: Holding their kiss. Eyes open in horror. Turn slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: He has his Video-8 to his eye and is taping the mcment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck and Ben are standing at the water's edge.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I think Dad's over-reacting to the involved father deal. I don't knew anybody who sees their dad all that much.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: You know, if he'd get wise to the fact that we love him just the way he is, it'd save us all a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Do you really care if he's a vast reservoir of North Woods lore?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You don't think he's going to make us sit on the porch and whittle, do you? Wally comes toddling down the bluff to the beach. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Howdy, sports! See Monster Mouth yer? Buck and Ben look at him like he's crazy. Wally cups his hand to his brow and looks out across the water.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (continuing) He's out there alright.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Who's Monster Mouth?

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Fish, son. Muskellunge. Related to your pikes and pickerels, only bigger and meaner than both you boys put together. The boys are skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (continuing) He's been out there for years. Nobody's caught him yet. Too smart. Plenty of you city dweller types go out there aiming to haul him in. And plenty of you die in his jaws. Brutal, old, bloodthirsty peckerhead, he is. {sneaks a look to see if he's scaring the boys) So, if you fellas go out there in God's pool, you make sure you take a parent or guardian along. And if they've got a weapon, remind them to bring it. I don't need to be cleaning guts up off the beach. I got plenty of other things to do. Ben and Buck look out across the water.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (continuing) By the way, don't you boneheads do no diving off the dock. I don’t need no lawsuits. Be winks and heads up the bluff. Buck and Ben look out across the lake. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: That was bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. They look out at the lake for a moment. They feel. strange sensations. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you sense the presence of an alien life form?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Now that you mention, I do. They slowly turn and look down the dock. THEIR P.O.V. The twins stand shoulder-to-shoulder at the end of the dock.

dialogues.speaker: TWINS
dialogues.text: Blank, spooky, Frozen expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet and Roman are sitting on the porch, sipping cock- tails from juice glasses.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I still can't picture you enjoying a vacation in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Me either. But Katie wanted to be with Connie. You know, you guys pimp us every time we invite you to the Islands. I can't resist Katie when she begs for something. Roman stirs his drink with his baby finger. His pinkie ring clinks against the glass. He looks at Chet with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You really dig this shit, don't you? ” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chet gives Roman a weary look.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) The woods. Hunting, fishing, camping, boating, mosquitoes, gnats, raccoons, stuffed fish, pine trees, cabins that smell like piss... . Chet nods. He ignores the insulting tone.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sand in your bed, cleaning perch, listening to bugs rubbing their legs together. (looks at his glass) Drinking Tanqueray out of a Jabba the Hut glass. Horseshoes, paper plates, calamine lotion, ticks, _chiggers, mildew, poison oak, ivy and summack, lake weeds that wrap around your ankles when you swim...

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (interrupts) What happened to the European trip?

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Katie wanted to do this. She was worried about the terrorism thing. Personally, I think it's a lot hippier to get blown-up in the Rome airport than it is to die of boredom in the woods. But rule number one, I run my home democratically, and Kate and the girls wanted to come up here to spend time with Connie and the boys, so here we are. I have to eat about six grand in deposits but what the hell, we're all here together and that's what matters.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (hoping against hope) Six grand's a lot of money to throw away. Maybe you should reconsider. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Forget it. Money grows on trees.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I wish.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: As far as I'm concerned, it does, but we'll get into that later. The point is, money grows on trees, good family relationships don't. Six grand is a small price to pay to see our two families together, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: {reluctantly) Right.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: You bet. So, anyway, you're an intelligent man, you make a good living, you got some options, why the heck would you want to come up to this plant~infested no~-man's land and live like a barbarian for a week? Chet looks at Roman. He's stunned that Roman can so easily trash nis vacation in one sentence. Roman is unaware that he's insulting Chet. He sincerely be- lieves he's just speaking truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're standing at the end of the dock staring out into the lake. THEIR P.O.V. The still water is suddenly disturbed as a mammoth fish leaps from the water and splashes down.

dialogues.speaker: TWINS
dialogues.text: Their eyes are wide in terror. They scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman and Chet continue their conversation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You gotta admit that this is some kind of country. Chet smiles fondly as he looks out on the lake and the surrounding forest. An unexpected moment of appreci- ation and sensitivity from Roman.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: You know what I see when I look out there? THEIR P.O.V. The most beautiful forest imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: He sweeps his hand across the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: I see the underdeveloped resources of Northern Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan. I see a syndicated development consortium exploiting a gocd billion and a half doliars in forest products. Lumber, pulp, animal skins, exotic game meats, rare mushrooms, medicinal fungi, firewood. I see clearing out the prime timber, the pelts, the ducks and whatever other miscellaneous salables are out there. A paper mill and if the metals are there, a mining operation. A green belt between condos on the lake and a waste management facility, focusing on the newest rage in toxic waste, medical refuse. Infected bandages, bedy parts, IV tubing, contaminated glassware, entrails, syringes, blood fluids, low-grade radioactive waste. All safely contained for centuries. What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Just trees, Roman. Just trees. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Well, no one ever accused you of having the grand vision and maybe that's for the best, huh? while the ambitious scramble for wealth and power, tne Chet Ripley's of the world are able to just casually stroll along life's path. That's a compliment because the rest of us are probably going to have strokes and die long before you.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Yeah, probably. That's what I'm hoping. (standing) I’m gonna stroll down life's path to the barbecue and start the hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Hot dogs? No relatives of mine are going to settle for hot dogs as long as they're sharing my cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobster tails are roasting on the grill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman's tending the tails. Chet's sitting in a patio chair, stewing.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Did I tell you what we did last week in the Euro-currency futures market?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: I thought I might have mentioned how a couple of weeks ago I bought a Deutchmark contract, sat on ita week, and sold it, taking a 300% profit? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: @ He glances over his shoulder to see if Chet's im- pressed.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Easy money is money easily lost.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Look what I pull down a year versus what you pull down. Do you think I work any harder than you? I doubt it. You're drawing a check from a company that's cleaning up on your sweat. You're a new age slave, Chet.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I'm in the auto parts business. I've been in it for fifteen years. They've done well by me and I've done weil by them.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: You don't think the chairman of your company would sell the goddamn works if he had the @ chance? Auto parts is a hot business.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: They're always going to need a regional manager no matter who owns the company.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: . I can't believe how dangerously old fashioned your thinking is. Companies are valuable if they can be bought and sold. dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Maybe. The conversation dies. Buck has something on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Dad?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: I'm kind of wrestling with a concept and maybe you can help me out.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: T'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What do you do when you find something that you really sort of love and you know you have to leave in a week?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Is it a living thing?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: First of all you have to take care of it. You have to make sure you poke enough holes in the lid of the jar you have it in. I had this same conversation with Ben and the toad he found. Then you have to feed it flies or bugs or worms or whatever it eats. And you have to give it water and clean the jar from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: My question was more about what do you do when you have to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You have to let it out of the jar. You can't take it home, if that's the next question. It wouldn't be fair. Everything has its place and your creature's place is here.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: I really like her, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Sure you do, and that's alright, but... It's a her?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Don't you have to look in their rear ends with a magnifying glass? Chet freezes.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: How do you tell the sex of a frog?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: She's not a frog, Dad. She's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You met a girl?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Why'd you lek me go on about jars and bugs and air holes?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: I understood what you were getting at.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, it still applies. Not the bugs and worms but how you have to deal with a person you meet on a trip. She can't come home with you and you can't stay here. It's easy to get your heart broken and to break hers if you're realistic about the situation and honest with each other.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You think about it and come to your own conclusions. You have my two cents but the decision's yours.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: No problem. Chet leans back and smiles at Buck. Buck smiles. Feels slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: One day you're little Bucky with the G.I. Joe's and the next you're with girls.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: This shouldn't be a surprise to you, Dad, this has been happening to people for a million years. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I know, but it hasn't been happening to me and you for a million years. I want to give you something.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Dad, please do not kiss me in a boat under a full moon.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Forget the kiss. I want to give you my ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Because my dad gave it to me and now you're grown up and I want to give it to you. Chet removes a ring from his finger. He hands it to Buck. He examines it.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (continuing) We'll get it resized when we get back home.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What about Ben?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I'll give him something when he's old enough.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Us coming up to the woods is like your father bringing you up to the woods. That makes sense, I guess. Be hands the ring back to Chet. Chet leans forward to take it. sudden shift in weight distribution. knees.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK'S HAND
dialogues.text: The ring flies out of Buck's hand. 75. 148 The boat rocks with the Chet falls to his (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EXT, WOODS
dialogues.text: A male black bear.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Drunk, slurry.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, WOODS
dialogues.text: They're sitting on a fallen tree. Roman's talking to the bear thinking it's Chet. Roman's winded.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: You move pretty good for a guy who doesn't work out. The bear GRUNTS.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Bless you. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, getting back to what I was saying on the porch before, in my opinion, you'ra a little toc conservative with your cash. The bear SNORTS.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have you been eating raw hot dogs again? Your breath could seduce a swarm of flies off a manure pile. He reaches into his pocket for his Binaca spray.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Open up.

dialogues.speaker: BEAR
dialogues.text: It opens its mouth as Roman's hand comes INTO FRAME with the mouthwash spray. A couple of short blasts in the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman puts the Binaca back.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: If you give me twenty-five grand, in six months I'll have a hundred for you. Sound good? (sniffs) You're taking this wilderness thing a bit far, aren't you? I can't imagine Connie going to bed with you smelling like you do. The bear GROWLS.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't get your nipples in a twist, I'm just pointing something out. I£ you want to smell like a goddam bear, it's fine with me. (continues) There's an immediate opportunity coming up and if we're going to move, we have to move fast. What do you say? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The bear knocks Roman to the ground. He picks himself up.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey! What's the big idea? If you don't want to invest, just tell me, don't go smacking me when L'm not looking! You just cool off, pal. I'm going back to the cabin. I suggest you do the same. We'll talk when you learn to channel your aggression a little better. He storms off. The bear watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck and Ben are in bed. There’s a KNOCK on the window. Buck sits up. There's another KNOCK. He climbs out of bed and walks cautiously to the window. Another KNOCK. He nervously takes the drape in his hand and yanks it open. It's Cammie. Buck's startled. He yanks the drape shut. He looks at himself in his underwear. He grabs his pants and throws them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck climbs out his window. Cammie helps him.

dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CAMMIE
dialogues.text: You didn't find me.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: I couldn't. There's an uncomfortable pause in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: (continuing) So what should we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rowboat's afloat in the middle of the lake. Bob- bing gently.  158 159 © 160

dialogues.text: Cammie and Buck are in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMIE
dialogues.text: go back to Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Four days.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMIE
dialogues.text: You know, I've never had a boyfriend for longer than two weeks. That's why I was such a dick to you the first night. And that's why I don't understand what I'm doing with you here.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: I've never really had a girlfriend. Honest. I've dated girls, but I've never had one I'd call a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMIE
dialogues.text: What would you call me? Buck looks at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lend.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMIE
dialogues.text: And you're leaving in four days. See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMIE
dialogues.text: Well? So what's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Life is tough? Cammie leans forward and kisses Buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The Raccoons return to the back porch and the garbage Once again, their CHIRPS are translated. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BABY RACCOON
dialogues.text: Mom? Do I have to be a racccon when I grow up. I hate working nights.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER RACCOON
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. Your father worked nights -- before he got hit by that truck. Your grandfather worked nights, and you'll work nights. You're nocturnal, and that's final. Now, get up there, and knock that rock off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Chet tries to pull the horse down the trail. It resists completely. Chet yanks and pulls. The horse nips at him. He threatens to punch the horse. It nips again. Chet's furious. He walks over to a sapling and pulls a branch off. .

dialogues.text: (continuing; I think we're all hurt. {to the twins) Girls? Are you hurt? They look at Roman and SHRIEK.

dialogues.text: Absolutely, Chet. He takes out his wallet. The Waitress cruises by. Roman hands her his American Express card.

dialogues.text: She eyes the proceedings with annoyed suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's truly worried.

dialogues.text: He turns back to Chet.

dialogues.text: A heavy refrigerator door. A sign reads... "HOME OF TRE OLD '96ER." The door slowly opens on a room filled with icy mist. The mist clears to reveal, with great drama, a single, massive steak hanging from a hook in the center of the locker.

dialogues.text: The giant four inch slab of meat slams down on the hot grill. The grill shudders under the impact.

dialogues.text: The Old '96er is sitting before him. A crowd is gathered around the table. Chet is stunned by the size of the steak. He looks at Connie as if he's going to be put to death. He looks at the kids. Buck gives him the thumbs-up. Roman opens a packet of Sweet 'N Low into hig coffee. Chet picks up his knife and fork. He takes a deep breath and makes the initial cut into the steak. The crowd leans forward as Chet brings the first bite to his mouth. He opens and consumes. The war has begun.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: He's chewing the bite, slowly and with some effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet has his jacket off, sleeves rolled up. The crowd hasn't diminished but has relaxed.

dialogues.text: It's half-finished.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: weary, tired and certainly full. He brings a bite to his mouth. He holds it before his open mouth. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: He smiles thinking Chet's had it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: He puts the bite in his mouth and continues.

dialogues.text: Cammie's still waiting. She looks at her watch again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Don't give up, big guy. Chet groans. Roman puts his head to Chet's belly and listens. :

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: He's disturbed to hear what appears to be SCREAMS.

dialogues.text: looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH
dialogues.text: Tt reads 9:32.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: TE you fail, we still owe the dinner tab plus $141.50 for the steak. I have a feeling if this Jimbo guy gets stiffed on the bill and his big steak, he'll beat up the wives and rape us. Chet leans forward, falls on his elbows. He grabs his knife and fork.

dialogues.text: She's afraid Chet might split open.

dialogues.text: He's nearly catatonic. Sweating like a Coke bottle in Nevada in August. Roman brings the fork up to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Open up, pal! Come on. Here comes the airplane! Open the airport! It's a nice little Lear jet with the Chairman of the Federal Resérve on hoard. Open wide. Chet looks up at Roman with bloodshot eyes. His mouth drops open. Roman puts the piece in his mouth. And closes it.

dialogues.text: As Chet chews, Roman walks over to Jimbo.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: I think that does it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: He's not done yet.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: He may take a while on that last bite but it'll go down.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: That ain't the last bite.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: Sure it is. All that's left on the plate is a bunch of fat. Jimbo smiles. Roman leans back in alarm. His eyes shift to Chet.  189 190 191 192 193 93.

dialogues.text: The door flies open and Chet staggers out to the applause of the other diners. The family comes out behind Chet. The kids are wearing big lumberjack hats. Chet's wearing a T-shirt... "I ATE A '96ER." He wanders to the car and leans against it. He sucks in the night air. Connie comforts him. Roman slaps him on the back. .

dialogues.speaker: . ROMAN
dialogues.text: Iwas just talking to Jimbo and here's the kicker, Chet. They don't take credit cards but they do take personal checks. I could have written a check for the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: He looks up at Roman. He wants to kill. He curls his lip and snarls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cammie's given up on Buck. She sighs and slides off the cooler. ” CAMMIE Never again will I do this to myself. They get what they want and they're gone.

dialogues.text: Roman's car pulls up in front of the cabin. Buck gets out and runs to the dock. Roman gets out. Connie, Kate and the twins get out. Chet's door opens and his legs drop out. He bellows in pain.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.text: Holy Jesus!
